Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE track 1: Asynchronous circuit design principles in the essential regulatory network of Caulobacter Crescentus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Software and Hardware Foundations Program in the Division of Computing and Communication Foundations in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, the Developmental Systems Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems in the Directorate for Biological Sciences, and the Biological and Computing Shared Principles working group.

Every cell contains an extremely complex control system for functions essential for survival and reproduction of the organism. Identification of the design principles embodied in this poorly understood core regulatory circuitry of the cell is the focus of this project. In many ways, this cellular control system resembles the electronic systems that humans design, although it uses biochemical and genetic reactions instead of transistors as its underlying technology. Over many decades, electrical engineers have learned design principles that enable the design of robust, reliable systems. This project investigates whether cellular control circuitry makes use of these same principles, and whether there are new principles that can be learned from cells. This is addressed by analysis of the essential logic controlling the bacterium Caulobacter crescentus. Caulobacter control circuitry resembles asynchronous digital circuits, a type of digital design that does not use a global clock signal to coordinate the system. The design of reliable asynchronous circuits is a difficult engineering challenge, and many interesting methods for designing and analyzing these circuits have been developed.

This project maps out the essential control circuitry, which regulates the processes that are vital to cell viability, using a combination of laboratory and computational methods. The research integrates results from several types of high-throughput data, including ribosome profiling, RNA-seq data at various points in the cell cycle, and ChIP-seq, and combines that with computational DNA binding motif search. A hybrid continuous and discrete mathematical model will be developed for the essential cell regulatory system, and a homologous asynchronous digital circuit will be constructed and analyzed using model checking software. The circuit structure and model checking results are used to map existing asynchronous circuit design concepts to the biological domain, and to identify new circuit design methods that may have been selected by evolution that lead to the extreme robustness displayed by living cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes

This was an interdisciplinary project with investigators from biology, computer science, and electrical engineering. The goal was to deepen understanding of the biochemical and genetic regulatory network that controls the cell cycle of the model bacterium Caulobacter crescentus. Caulobacter is of particular interest because it divides asymmetrically to produce two differentiated daughter cells: a “swarmer” cell with a flagellum that which provides motility and a “stalked” cell which has a multifunctional stalk appendage. Only the stalk cell type is competent to initiate chromosome replication and cell division. After a short period of motility, the swarmer ejects its flagellum, differentiates into the stalked cell type, and then initiates another cycle of cell duplication and division. Over the past 40 years, the molecular and genetic mechanisms of the complex Caulobacter cell cycle have been intensively studied so that now Caulobacter is the best understood model at the molecular level of how cells accomplish asymmetric division.  This is a profoundly important current problem in the biological sciences and medicine.

In this project, we focused on understanding essential regulatory genes, that is the subset of genes that are essential for Caulobacter viability. Regulatory genes encode proteins that control the synthesis of other proteins, some of which can also have a regulatory function.

Intellectual merit

The project produced several important insights into Caulobacter cell which are described in publications by the team.  The first paper1 identifies cell cycle-regulated genes and characterizes details of their regulation with unprecedented accuracy. The paper offers new insights into how some genes are subject to combinatorial control by multiple regulatory mechanisms simultaneously.  This enables the cell to adjust the rate of progression of the cell cycle in response to conditions in the environment or internal to the cell.

A second paper2 provides a detailed characterization of cell cycle-dependent regulation of translation (the synthesis of proteins from information encoded in messenger RNAs), a topic that has previously not been investigated in bacteria. We showed that polar-located proteins are synthesized in a narrow time window just when needed for insertion at the proper pole and that cell cycle-dependent translation is controlled by the same cyclical biochemical circuit that controls gene transcription. This is an important advance in our standing of the bacterial cell cycle control system.

One of the goals of the project was to understand the control of the cell cycle as an “asynchronous circuit” – a digital circuit with no central clock.  This project has led us to a deeper investigation of methods for designing fault-tolerant asynchronous circuits – circuits that continue to function despite limited internal faults, such as transient changes that are not supposed to occur or signals that don’t change when they are supposed to (“stuck-at faults”).  It is interesting that Caulobacter has evolved a cell cycle circuit design that does not get “stuck” in a state where it cannot proceed, in most circumstances. We are continuing to explore, after the grant, new ways to design electrical asynchronous circuits that similarly avoid getting  stuck in a particular state. 

Finally, we discovered a protein, GapR, that is an essential regulator of the Caulobacter cell cycle3. GapR has proven to have an unusual mechanism of action that is the subject of ongoing research.

Broader outcomes

The project contributed to training several students and a post-doctoral scholar. Three computer science undergraduates participated in the project over the summer and during the academic year.  Both have graduated and now work in the bio-medical industry, and one is the MS program in biomedical informatics at Stanford.  A postdoc involved in the research is now a scientist at a company that is developing new antibiotics.  A PhD student in electrical engineering is continuing research on biological fault-tolerant circuits. Owing to the cross-disciplinary nature of the project, the individual participants gained a much deeper understanding of the nature of biological functions than results from traditional training paths.

Publications partially supported by this grant:

  1. Bo Zhou, Jared M Schrader, Virginia S Kalogeraki, Eduardo Abeliuk, Cong B Dinh, James Q Pham, Zhongying Z Cui, David L Dill, Harley H McAdams, and Lucy Shapiro. The global regulatory architecture of transcription during the Caulobacter cell cycle. PLoS genetics, 11(1):e1004831, 2015.
  2. Jared M. Schrader, Gene-Wei Li, W. Seth Childers, Adam Perez, Jonathan S. Weissman, Lucy Shapiro, Harley H. McAdams (2016). Dynamic translation regulation in Caulobacter cell cycle control.  Proceedings of the National Academy USA. 
  3. Ricci DP, Melfi MD, Lasker K, Dill DL, McAdams HH, Shapiro L., “Cell cycle progression in Caulobacter requires a nucleoid-associated protein with high AT sequence recognition” Proceedings of the National Academy USA, Epub ahead of print Sep 19, 2016.
